I'm so going to sleep in tomorrow.

Got as far as petulant children and realized you weren't worth reading.  This executive order is nothing more than a petulant child of a president lashing out after his party lost the Senate and more of the House.  Tit for tat, huh?

"The problem, of course, is that the base of the GOP is so angered by …" the fact that a black man won the votes of most Americans … twice. OUCH! that hurt.  And he gets the country out of the GOOP created recession and makes the country prosperous again … OUCH! How uppity can he get?

Paul Hackett

And the Republican party does everything it can to destroy peaceful upward economic advancement, it attacks a minimum wage, labor unions and a progressive income tax, three factors responsible for the explosion in our middle class after WWII.

The GOP is NOT in favor of a real, liveable salary for those working in the fields dominated by undocumented workers, the Republicans like that cheap labor aspect with none of the rights for workers, which makes the party's caterwauling about "amnesty" as the completely hypocritical screeching it so obviously is.

Only when anyone playing the sham "amnesty" card works in the fields by harvesting their own crops, or laboring in slaughter houses & processing plants can they have even the least modicum of knowing what they're blathering about.

It's easy to condemn undocumented immigrants and talk with your mouth full, especially when you're not doing the hard, dirty, dangerous jobs yourself.

The GOP is continuing to act like the same petulant children that they have been for the past six years. While the issue triggering their behavior changes, the GOP's reckless willingness to threaten the economic health and credit rating of our country if they don't get exactly their way hasn't.

What distinguishes this episode from the previous obstructionist showdowns is that it isn't entirely clear what the GOP's problem is. As President Obama has repeatedly made clear, the GOP can address the immigration issue by the House taking a vote on an immigration reform bill that has broad majority support in both houses of Congress and among the American people. Immigration reform has already passed the Senate 68-32, with 14 Republic votes. And it could easily pass the House if Boehner would let it come up for a vote. Instead, Boehner refuses and conservatives are having one of their overwrought freak outs over President Obama taking executive action on immigration just as Presidents Reagan and Bush did.

The problem, of course, is that the base of the GOP is so angered by the increasing Latino population in our country that they are virulently opposed to anything short of getting undocumented immigrants to "self-deport." That base is holding the GOP hostage and the GOP, in turn, is threatening to hold our economy and government hostage. President Obama should call their bluff and not give in to yet more hostage taking by the GOP.

I agree with you in what you say here is largely garbled and makes no sense.

First this article is not about the ACA but the unpopularity of Obamacare is largely a product of massive media messaging against it.

Healthcare cost were too high % wise and too high and rising to quickly for our entire society. Something had to be attempted, all reasonably informed would agree. Furthermore, because of "pre-existing procedure" clauses, health care insurance was anything but assurance that one was insured. EVERBODY is cleared of that stalking, haunting spector by the ACA. Your assumption also relies upon the idea that American's are entirely and thoroughly selfish and couldn't care less about anyone else. My personal experience suggest that only a small % are. You've been victimized into framing things in a Fox based world.

The history of environmental legislation looks pretty good, until Reagan and the 1/10%ers took over. Ozone legislation and anti-pollution measures were not hated by the public and had very limited impact on economics. I've been to Korea where the massive POSCO Pohang Iron and Steel Works sits on a bay with crystal clear water with fishing boats anchored in it and I've been to Gary, Indiana where the waterways are poisoned within 10 miles of the massive mills there. While American steel struggled, POSCO went on to become one of the worlds giant steel firms.

Lesson: Pollution is a choice, not an inevitability of economic growth.

De-foxify yourself.
I have found hussmanfitness.org to be really informative about the science and chemistry of calorie consumption, weight loss and exercise

What I Love about this article is seeing curiosity once again in the medical field. Nothing is this article is put forth as FACT, there is simply curiosity. I Love That. As someone who has been diagnosed and misdiagnosed with endless maladies - some psychological and some physical, it is refreshing to see Curiosity, a willingness to NOT accept something as rote, but tearing off the label and entertaining that there may be no one answer or set group of answers. If only we could all do that in our daily lives... I wonder what kind of world we would live in if more curiosity prevailed?

I suspect that Santa, buying toys for those little boys, wasn't as enlightened as you are in 1901.  But I'm glad now is now.

With all respect Charlotte, I challenge your view. I Have been labeled as being depressed my entire life, even when I am content. I have felt what you describe above. We are all different, and respond to everything differently, but I have found that it is in my darkest and most alone hours, when I and everything around me seem broken beyond repair, that those are the ripest times to cultivate and practice meditation and mindfulness. They may Not make things better, but they Can allow you to see things in different ways that are not further damaging. Those times can can actually be an opportunity to Be inside that grey or black blanket and explore it. I do not discard that medication or other treatments can help and Are necessary at times, and I also do not discard the power of healing the self through meditation and mindfulness. Meditation/Mindfulness need not be high minded or lofty. In fact they are not - you start with small doses just like you do with medication.

The more research is done, the more it appears that depression isn't simply a single disease or group of diseases, but a symptom that can occur in a large number of disorders. These can be neurological, endocrine, a combination of the two (think of stress, acute or chronic, and the associated hormonal imbalances), inflammatory (including auto-immune disorders, and with possible infection-caused triggering mechanisms), or even related to neoplasms (tumours), benign or malignant. This doesn't mean there's no place for supportive psychotherapy - if anything, it means there are plenty of situations that call for it - but it does hint that there can be many dimensions to this particular enigma. So far, if there's anything about depression of which we can be certain, it's that trying to help the afflicted by simply telling them to 'cheer up' makes about as much sense as trying to turn Alaska into a tropical paradise by planting some palm trees.

Everyone should invite and encourage the social apps, it will solve the so many major problems we are facing in our day today life. Even our traffline creates traffic app to give the navigation map to all rider and it is userfriendly. http://bit.ly/TraffApp

When the bank undertakes to make loans guaranteed by the FHA, they commit to doing certain things, one of which is to contact a potentially defaulting borrower to try to make arrangements which will avoid default. U.S. Bank has not--according to the Advocates for Basic Legal Equality--even given this commitment lip service. But FHA loans are intended to be made to borrowers who are less wealthy and less financially sophisticated, and for whom such am offering to help avoid default has real value.

I feel the FHA has been defrauded by these claims where no effort at mitigation was made.

I agree that making such efforts to help borrowers avoid default and foreclosure will certainly cost the lenders and their loan servicers money. But that is part of what they undertook as part of the loan guarantee program. There was no clause in that agreement which said they could be excused if they felt it would cost too much.

The Justice Department is totally wrong in this case.

A research study some years back found that depressed patients who worked with the soil improved.  Perhaps some healthful bacteria in the soil may counteract the overgrowth of some undesirable microbes or may decrease inflammation.  Unfortunately, there's no goose to lay a golden egg if soil microbes turn out to be a treatment for depression, so to date there has been insufficient research in this area.   Psychiatry is too dependent on Big Pharma for research on mental illness.   Instead we need multi-disciplinary teams that look at varied treatments and off-label uses of generic medications, as well as different models of psychotherapy, plus data experts that can set up computer models to facilitate comparisons and common demographic and/or genetic factors.   Perhaps such studies can lead to clinical tests to help clinicians determine optimal individualized treatment speedily, without so much trial and error and poor outcomes.

It's 43A that I wanted to comment on. The correct answer as clued would be AQABA.  The name of the Gulf, here, is Gulf of Eilat. We see the town of Aqaba across the water, its hotels and lights, and there is some travel between the two.

MB, indeed, and thanks for the link.  However, there is no point is not trying, since we are still alive and vertical.  Once horizontal, it will no longer be our problem. I am a big fan of EcoWatch but have been busy myself, and of course as she says, it's no excuse.
That would be Steingraber and Krugman, but otherwise I stand by the material.

In the interests of knowing why we are in the midst of one of history's great failures in communication, this:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K3BlotUe4G8

One might be ambivalent about the style (though his substance is largely true) of Russell Brand's responses, but the woman is a stark example of effective counterfactual PR propaganda.

It does not work to flood the airwaves with logic, compassion, and good sense.

However, this sendup has the facts largely right, we are in a planetary emergency, and people are playing oppo research instead of paying attention to the biggest crises in the history of humankind, and we've had a few (the plague). Science is not a matter for "belief" but for understanding: it's the best we've got, and our most intelligent and knowledgeable expertise has been hammering at the door for the better part of four decades.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6CXRaTnKDXA

This recently came to my attention, on activism and tradeoffs. I have nothing like the moral fiber of Sandra Steainhaber or Paul Drugman, but it is important at that scale to act, and act now. Not later, but yesterday.
http://ecowatch.com/2014/11/24/crappy-mom-manifesto/

J Hough, you appear to think your flat assertion makes it so.  Why are you incurious as to why a vast majority of the world's expertise runs counter to your opinion?  What makes you think that the science that allows us to communicate and you to be comfortable with mod cons is meaningless when you don't want to pay attention?
"Close family members" surely suggests a genetic factor? Also there is a possible connection with thyroid disorders, no?

Interesting and thought provoking, I wonder if any drug company is sponsoring this research and if so, I would like to know.

Alternate medicine or medical approaches are wonderful and I hope the researchers would continue it to its logical ends.

Most new findings in medicine or other sciences do happen when we question the old methods or/and theories. If we didn't the earth would still be flat (not Tom Friedman’s version but year 1000 version).

These are the types of research that must be supported by NIH or other government agencies because these are not the types of research major pharma would be interested in. Just imagine if Depression is treated by a drug to address the underlying causes such as inflammation or other infections. The medicine would eventually culminate at the end of its course. The medicine will not be perpetual where these major pharma makes tons of money.

As I do not suffer from the illness my experience is from close family members who are and have suffered this dreaded disease. It is very possible that it is an infectious disease and inflammation effects the brain to process/delay the process of information due to either lack of proper circulation or presence of other enzymes in the systems of the body. It is also possible that the patient’s ability to process the information is so affected that it generates anger and frustration which in turn generate a feeling of helplessness etc. and so on.

Hyper-partisanship and polarization have provided cover for and exacerbated the extremes in both parties in ways that never would have existed in decades past.

Now, for example, religious intolerance will be defended vociferously by democrats because of a desire to push back against the extremist views of the religious right, when democrats would have been defending Hobby Lobby's religious speech a few decades ago.
Would that old leadership of a believable Democratic Party even let the radical extremists running their party today in the room?

This is pretty simple but involves admitting errors.

The Democratic Party once stood for huge parts of America, like the middle class, workers, and against communism. It was friendly toward capitalism to a point and religion in all forms.

Today, the Dems have told most of those people to take a hike while it zeroes in on 3 or 4 client groups and offers itself up to them like a floozy desperate for love, not even aware of how rapidly it changes its mind.

Today's Dems have totally abandoned the worker, leaving its old base open to both of the pro-constitution groups, Conservatives and Libertarians.

Sen. Chuckie Schumer made a lot of sense recently, which is why flying monkeys on broomsticks swirl around his head right now. Why not follow along with the most respected Dem Senator?

and Elke,
